abstract.text: Partition multisport and interval workouts into activities that represent the different parts of the workout.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Dividing a HealthKit workout into activities

inlineContent.text: Some workouts benefit from having the workout’s duration broken into a set of discrete activities. For example, a multisport event, like a triathlon, has separate swim, bike, and run portions. Similarly, you can divide interval training into active and rest periods.
To model these activities in HealthKit, use the
class to specify the different parts of a workout. You can then query for workouts that have matching activities, and analyze those activities independently from the rest of the workout.
instances have two main use cases:
For workouts with an
activity type, you can use
instances to represent the
, and
portions of the workout. You can also use activities to mark the
between these activities.
Multisport workouts
Use
instances to represent the active portions of the workout. You can create an interval workout for any
; however, all workout activities must use the same activity type as the containing workout. You can’t mix activities within a single workout.
Interval training
All
objects have at least one associated
. If you don’t explicitly add an activity to a workout, HealthKit adds an activity that matches the workout’s activity type. This means you can use
to filter for all the workouts that track an activity type. For example, filtering for workout activities that use
includes regular running workouts, running interval training, and
workouts that include a running activity.
Activities can’t overlap, but they also don’t need to cover the entire

sample’s duration. You can leave the time between the active portions of the workout blank, or you can explicitly create workout activities for these intervals. For example, explicitly creating activities for the time between active portions of the workout helps you track statistics during those intervals.
For multisport workouts, you can explicitly mark the transitions between activities using an

type. For interval training, you can use the same activity type as the workout for the rest periods; however, you may want to add custom metadata to indicate whether the activity is an active or resting interval.

How you choose to model the data depends on the needs of your app and the types of intervals you’re tracking. If you’re tracking a workout that alternates between a fast and a slow pace, using workout activities to explicitly track all intervals makes sense. If, however, the intervals alternate between exercising and resting (for example, during many high-intensity interval training exercises), you may want to leave the rest intervals blank.

content.text: Add workout activities to a workout session

inlineContent.text: To add workout activities to a workout session, start by creating the session and start collecting data using the workout builder.

code: // Create the workout configuration for a multisport workout.
// Start the session and the workout builder.
// Set the workout builder's data source.

inlineContent.text: Next, when an activity begins, create a new configuration for the activity, and start the activity using the session’s
method. The data source automatically begins collecting the default data types for the activity.
When the activity ends, call the session’s
method. HealthKit also ends the current activity when you begin a new activity.
To explicitly track the intervals between activities, start a new activity using
. End this transition when the next activity begins.

code: // Explicitly track the transition between activities.

inlineContent.text: Finally, when the entire workout session ends, call the session’s
method. This also ends the current activity. Then call the workout builder’s
method to save the workout to the HealthKit store. This method also returns an
object, which you can use to display summary information about the workout.

code: // Ending the session also ends the current activity.
// Finishing the workout saves the workout
// and returns an HKWorkout object that you can use to display summary data.
// Do something with the workout here.

content.text: Enable and disable the collection of data

inlineContent.text: When you start a new workout activity, your data source automatically begins collecting relevant data from Apple Watch. To see the data types that the data source collects, check the data source’s
property.
When running an
workout session, HealthKit automatically changes the collected data types based on the current workout activity. For example, the data source collects data like
, and
If you start an
activity, the system automatically updates the data source’s
property based on the new activity. For example, the data source automatically stops collecting
and
, and starts collecting relevant data like
and
Most of the time, you can use the default collected data types. However, if your app calculates and saves its own
objects during the workout, you may want to manually enable and disable the collection of that data type, letting the data source automatically associate your samples with the workout.
To start collecting a data type, call the data source’s
method.

code: // Enable the collection of respiratory rate.

inlineContent.text: HealthKit then associates any matching samples from your app with the workout activity. You can also disable the collection of a data type by calling

code: // Disable the collection of respiratory rate.

inlineContent.text: To query for workouts with activities that match a specific predicate, start by creating a workout activity predicate using one of the
class’s
methods. Next, use
to wrap the activity predicate inside a workout predicate. You can then use the workout predicate in your query.

code: // Create a predicate for an average heart rate of greater than 150 bpm.
// Wrap the workout activity predicate inside a workout predicate.
let matchingWorkouts = try await query.result(for: store)
// Do something with the samples here.

inlineContent.text: This example returns all the workouts that have an activity with an average heart rate over 150 bpm. Use the workout’s
property to access the activities associated with a workout.

abstract.text: Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the user’s privacy and control.
Stops automatically calculating statistics for the quantity type.
Begins automatically calculating statistics for samples that match the quantity type and predicate.
A quantity sample type that measures the amount of active energy the user has burned.
A quantity sample type that measures the distance the user has moved while swimming.
A quantity sample type that measures the distance the user has moved by walking or running.
A quantity sample type that measures the distance covered by a single step while running.
A quantity sample type that measures the number of strokes performed while swimming.
An abstract class for all the query classes in HealthKit.
Returns a predicate for workout activities based on the type of activity performed.
Returns a predicate for matching workouts based on the associated workout activities.
A HealthKit sample represents a piece of data associated with a start and end time.
A workout sample that stores information about a single physical activity.
An object that describes an activity within a longer workout.
The type of activity performed during a workout.
The constant for cycling.
The constant for running and jogging.
The constant for multisport activities like triathlons.
The constant for swimming.
A constant for the transition time between activities in a multisport workout.
A builder object that incrementally constructs a workout.
Creates the workout, using the samples and events added to the builder, and saves it to the HealthKit store.
An object representing an important event during a workout.
Begins a new workout activity in the workout session.
Ends the workout session.
Ends the current workout activity.
The type of session.
A type that identifies samples that store information about a workout.
The workout type identifier.
Read series data from condensed workouts.
Create associated samples that add details to a workout.
Manage workouts, workout sessions, and activity summaries.

media-4083470.alt: An illustration showing a .swimBikeRun workout and its corresponding .swimming, .biking, .running, and .transition activities. The activities fill the entire time covered by the workout, but none of the activities overlap.
